Colin, I don't think there is any agreed standard set.  However, I generall=
y recommend not having more than one of each kind.  For example, Gaussian i=
s symmetric and Abs is also symmetric, so I would go without the Abs. Sine =
and cosine are also similar.    Also, a low-frequency sine wave may not be =
much different from a signed sigmoid.  The issue is whether we are just thr=
owing a ton of stuff into the mix for no principled reason.

I also agree t=
hat something like an unbounded linear function can have unintended consequ=
ences.  

My guess is that even sigmoids and Gaussians alone can work well,=
 although it's just a hunch. 

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Gree=
n <colin.green1@...> wrote:
>
> Hi all,
> 
> Just wondering what are curren=
tly considered to be the standard set of
> CPPN activation functions. I fig=
ure they are:
> 
> Sigmoid
> Gaussian
> Abs
> Sine
> 
> Although reading th=
rough the papers I think one of them omitted
> Sigmoid and Jef Clune's pape=
r used a whole load more...
> 
> Cosine
> Square
> Linear
> One's complemen=
t (I figure this is just a sign flip, yes?)
> 
> There may be other variati=
ons, these are just some I spotted just now.
> 
> Colin
>
